App description:
Step inside a galaxy far, far away with Vader Immortal: Episode I. You are a smuggler operating near Mustafar, the fiery world Darth Vader calls home. When you are unexpectedly pulled out of hyperspace, you find yourself uncovering an ancient mystery at the behest of the Sith Lord himself.

With the help of your droid companion, ZO-E3, youll navigate the dangers of the fortress, hone your lightsaber skills, and meet new characters along the way as you discover what Vader is up to.

Also included with your purchase is Lightsaber Dojo, an open-ended training experience where you can hone your skills with the weapon of a Jedi Knight.

Starring Maya Rudolph, Vader Immortal is a canonical Star Wars adventure created by ILMxLAB and Lucasfilm in collaboration with Oculus Studios.

Like living inside a Star Wars movie

Episode One is the real deal. You will be transported from your bedroom to planet Mustafar, where the surface is covered with rivers flowing with lava. There you will learn how to use a light saber to deflect laser gun fire and battle with light saber wielding robots.

This is a great experience where you can sit through most of it. The only time youll need to get up is during the light saber battles b/c some of your enemies come from behind.

You can use your controllers to move through the environments so that it feels like youre walking through the Darth Vaders fortress. There are a few places where you can just stop and admire the environment, but most of the time one of the characters prompts you to keep following them. But if you want the best experience just follow the intended pace of the experience because it allows for best immersion.

You can go back into the game another time and just sit outside the fortress to admire the volcanic landscape.

This is a good experience for newbies to VR because your sidekick robot voiced by Maya Rudolf gives suggestions like hit the buttons on the hyper drive, while youre standing near a panel of switches.

But I do think it is aimed at those who are at a minimum a casual gamer because you will have to fight using a light saber and that requires fulling committing to a battle in virtual reality. It really looks like someone is about to slice you wide open with a saber.

Im a 55 year old casual gamer who started with the 8-bit Nintendo NES, and its amazing to see how far video games have come.

Come for the story, stay for the dojo

My first purchased game for the Quest - not disappointed ! Right from the start, feeling like you're actually in a Star Wars ship that's about to make the jump to hyperspace... what more could you want ? Hugely immersive all the way to the finish. It must be said that this is more of an interactive story than a game, but it's none the worse for that - largely because the story itself fits the Star Wars universe perfectly, and also because this is extremely well designed for the space limitations of VR. Nice graphics, perfect performance, tremendous fun.

The story is short, but the training dojo is certainly not. 40 addictive levels of lightsaber duelling with training droids of progressively higher skill. I'm on level 39 after lord-knows how much time and I'm still totally enthralled by it. Because, well, you get to hit stuff with a lightsabre, and that just never gets old... you even need to listen to determine where the next attack is coming from. The story has replayability, but the dojo is something I've taken to using as daily exercise (probably because I'm not very good at it, so I end up doing all kinds of crazy twister-like moves just to not die). I end up sweating profusely and enjoying every second of it.

Absolutely worth $10. Just be aware the story mode, while excellent, doesn't last very long. Unless you're the only Star Wars fan in existence who doesn't enjoy hitting stuff with a lightsabre, though, I assure you that that isn't going to matter.

This is not a game, just cutscenes

I've been excited about this one since I got an Oculus, but held off til I had store credit. Visually it's nice, but I have a few gripes. It doesn't put you eye to eye with people you would be speaking to. I'm looking down at them, hovering above. This makes Vader much less imposing when he looks like he's a foot and a half shorter than you.

It's nice they got the real deal voice. This part of the 3 part VR series sets up a story to play through, but just that's where the actual lack of gameplay hinders this.

This portion of this mini series is very orchestrated. Follow a very narrow path, climb some ladders, get lightsaber and go through a pretty soft tutorial (which is unneeded with the available dojo anyways), have literally three mini battles. The battles are very one-on-one, quite the opposite of a game like Pistol Whip. Then as the story starts to get exciting, this part is done and it just feels like an upsell to keep playing.

The fights have you locked to a spot on the floor, unable to move on the screen (the opposite of Robo Recall, for example). Gameplay felt clunky, there are definitely more fluid games out there that I have mentioned in this review.

Probably something neat to show new to VR people as the controls are very simple, the dojo may have some minor replayability, but this would be a demo or $2.99 "game" if not connected to Star Wars. Playable, bit feels like it's just trying to sell the next little piece.

Short but Well Made Experience

Graphics: 9/10
Gameplay: 6/10
Story: 9/10
Length: 1-2 hours story, 5-10 hours of replay-ability in "Lightsaber Dojo Mode"
Overall: 5/5 stars (Worth the price)

I got this game bundled with my Oculus Quest, so it was among the first experiences I played. I enjoyed playing through the story mode, maintaining engagement throughout the entire time. While I played, I hardly noticed any glaring issues with bugs, and thought the graphics were impressive considering this is being run by a mobile processor. A few weeks later, much of this opinion I still stand by today, though some things have changed.

Pros:
- Graphics: One of the more visually impressive games on the quest, looks great
- Comfort Options: I don't get motion sickness in VR, but if you do there are teleportation and smooth locomotion options available.
- Few bugs interrupted the experience
- Story was enjoyable, although rather short
- Combat in wielding the lightsaber was smooth and enjoyable
- Climbing felt tense, especially during the "Ascent" section
- Lightsaber Dojo adds some replayability

Cons:
- Graphics don't compare to PCVR games, but this is to be expected of course
- Game is really short
- Completely linear experience, so if you are looking for a more 'open' game, this won't be it
- The physics of getting stuck in walls was really immersion breaking at times

Overall, I do recommend this game to anyone who likes Star Wars, and consider it a must buy for the Oculus Quest.

AlexixxDec 7 at 12:49 AM
This Game Is Not Short

All the people complaining about how "short" the game is are misunderstanding something. The story mode where you follow the robot and see Vader, that is not the actual game. That's just the background lore if anything else.

The REAL game you're buying here is lightsaber dojo. There are so many levels to go through, and each level gets progressively more challenging, requiring greater skill and awareness to complete. You can move to the next level without getting 3 marks, but it's best to completely master each level before moving to the next.

As you gain mastery, there will be more interesting opponents to fight and you will unlock additional kyber crystals to change the color of your lightsaber. You will need to adjust your form based on which opponent you are facing if you wish to survive without being hit, which is required to master the level.

I'm currently on level 9, this game more than anything else gives me the feeling of training to be a jedi master. At higher levels you need to listen very carefully in order to react to the incoming attacks in time, and some of these instances really give the illusion of learning to feel an attack coming via the Force.

So again, play through the story, because it is very cool and Darth Vader is quite intimidating in person. But don't think for a second that is where the game stops. That is only the beginning.

My only complaint is there are times where the blade can "bend" a little bit in certain instances (not always, just every once in a while) which doesn't really feel like a lightsaber should move that way. It's not incredibly noticeable, but it certainly loses to the sabers in beat saber in terms of sturdiness. That being said, I really love the design of the handle and the vaporous glow of the blades are quite pretty.

Vader Immortal: Episode 1 is what fans of Star Wars dream of, to become a Jedi warrior. The game has great controls and wielding the lightsaber is smooth and great. I have yet to try Lightsaber dojo, but it personally sounds like a fun arcade experience. However, the campaign mode leaves a lot to be desired.
The story isn't anything new compared to your average Star Wars story. You begin as a nobody and eventually become a rookie jedi. However, the story is very short. Everything goes by way too quickly and when the episode is over, you're left feeling like it ended way too soon and there should've been more. Might be a creative choice in order to push customers to buy the other episodes, but I can say this now: each epsiode is very fast and the whole trilogy can be beaten within hours. The story is decent, but the experience is slightly ruined during scripted cutscenes where the game asks you to stay still, or when you step somewhere the game doesn't want you to be. The game demands that you stay where it wants you to be, and if you go outside the accepted area, everything goes black and the game asks you to return to the proper area. It could take you away from the experience and sometimes ruin it completely.
To conclude Vader Immortal is a fun game, however the game demands you to stay still during specific times and to not walk into certain areas, and if you do walk off you're taken out of the game, ruining the experience. Even then, the campaign goes by so fast, it leaves a lot to be desired, even after playing the whole trilogy of games.

Great VR but short

Vader Immortal is probably one of the best home VR experiences I've seen to date. It's less a game and more an interactive movie where you play a key actor. I'd liken the experience to going to a really great haunted house or a theme park ride. There are some combat and puzzle elements but it's very linear and there no real stakes to missing a block and the puzzles don't get more complicated than simple switch throwing and knob turning. That said the experience is well voiced, well paced, and the sound track and sound effects are amazing. There are no real branching paths to the experience so replay value will be low for most. It does feature an arcade style lightsaber dojo that's far more of a game and will add some replay value/challenge. At ten buck I find it a great value and episode 2 is worth the price of continuing to me, but it's definitely a quality over quantity argument, don't expect a 40 hour triple a game.

johncuyleSep 19, 2019 at 10:31 PM
A must have despite its flaws.

If you have a Quest, you need this game. It's Star Wars, and it is very immersive. The first time I played I was in a very large play area and briefly forgot that I needed to move using the controls. I simply walked around the ship, and it was amazing.

Once you get into the game and start traversing the world, you'll be teleporting or sliding, which is, unfortunately, unavoidable. The experience still remains compelling though. For people who have never experienced VR but love Star Wars, this is the experience to show them (with motion set to teleport. I'm not prone to motion sickness but sliding takes a little getting used to before it stops being nausea inducing.)

Be advised, it's short and linear. It's priced reasonably for what you get though. Think of it as a VR comic with a bonus lightsaber game attached.

The problems:

Lightaber tracking is, unfortunately, pretty bad. A lot of what should be hits don't seem to connect for some reason and there's a frustrating and noticeable latency to it. Considering that this is a Star Wars game in which you wield a lightsaber as your only weapon, this really ought to be at least as responsive and accurate as Beat Saber since it is the majority of game play.

The dojo, in which you wield the lightsaber and which is the primary chunk of content, other than the story, restricts you to an incredibly small area of movement. This feels crippling when facing multiple enemies since you will naturally want to move to evade some attacks while deflecting others and you simply can't for no obvious good reason. Particularly because battles in the Star Wars universe tend to feature a lot of motion (think about Obi-Wan and Qui-Gon versus Maul, the hide and seek battle between Luke and Vader through the guts of Cloud City, or the battle traversing the Emporer's throne room.)

The game is great and I eagerly await the next installment. In the meantime, they probably can't change the motion limitations for the Dojo in this version because it would require very different tuning, but I desperately hope they can improve the saber tracking and collision to the point it is comparable with Beat Saber and other blade swinging titles. Star Wars deserves it.

Long Review Ahead

Alright, here's the deal. Yeah, chapter one is short. An introductory chapter is supposed to introduce you to the story, the characters, and the mechanics the rest of the game will have, which this does beautifully.

And to the people who say it's not 'interactive enough'. You're being ridiculous. How many games do you play where your choices ever truly affect the ending? (I'll give you a hint, none.) The writers are telling a story and they're not about to let some random player derail it. Enjoy their story or write your own.

Some people say it was too easy. Well yeah, the beginning of a game is always easier than the rest. You're supposed to be learning. If the fighting was easy for you, great! I'm sure it won't be in the future.

This chapter is amazingly fun to play through. The characters are fun, (dare I say life size without double checking my facts), and the story is engaging. Anyone who's familiar with the Star Wars universe at all will be able to understand and enjoy the story.

The mechanics of the game are easy enough to grasp that my father, who has previously never played VR nor enjoyed video games at all, was able to jump in and go.

Almost as soon as the game began, he was in awe. He was constantly looking around and trying to point out everything he could see. He loved it, and kept commenting on how real it felt. So real, that when (SPOILER ALERT: Darth Vader shows up) Vader first showed up, he panicked and ripped the headset off. The next day, he kept talking about how amazing the game play was, how he wants to finish it, and how my brother needs to play it as well to 'see how real it is'. He's even showing it to his siblings and coworkers. So, clearly, fun for all ages.

I highly recommend this game and all chapters that are coming (hopefully!) soon.

I thought that the graphics and tracking of this game really showed the capability of the quest. I was immersed the whole time and it felt truly real. The sense of scale was also phenomenal. Despite all of these positives, there were some setbacks, specifically the length. I was excited to keep going and then it just stopped. I looked to see if I was missing something but I wasnt. Many people told me that this game could take as long as you wanted to, or you could zoom through it in about 35 minutes. I tried to take my time but it still took only 45 minutes.

My next complaint is that I wasnt able to look around in my ship long enough, and the ship felt too small. Ive always wanted to be aboard a Star Wars ship and was slightly dissatisfied with this.

Another complaint is that it had some annoying glitches. One time, my droid asked me to grab onto their hand and then they never let go of my hand. They kept telling me, do you think you can open that door over there? And I found myself yelling at the droid, no cause you wont let go of me! I had to restart the game to get through this.

My last complaint is that the dojo was underwhelming. Overall, I think the game was great but short lived, and I think the $9.99 price tag was too much. I would have been a lot more satisfied with a $4.99 or even $6.99 price tag.

However they are using the controller tracking data it is like your saber only exists for each split second it is tracked. So if you swing fast at something you can miss it entirely, especially the small ball droids. If you swing too fast you just dont hit them at all. HaradRoadJun 1, 2019 at 9:19 PM
Read the description of the game

"immersive cinematic storytelling with dramatic interactive play".

This is not a 20 hour repetitive low polygon game it seems so many people like. This is called an EXPERIENCE yet I still call it the best VR has to offer to date. While it is not as long as we all want, it definitely delivers an immersive experience and is fun to play leaving you wanting more. One of those VR games where the online web video of it does not do it justice until you put the headset on and play then go ..WOW!

I understand the <5 feedback on it, but this is one of those purchases that deliver and you cannot avoid being pulled into the thrill of it and the inevitable "grin" many mention that they leave with (I did). The fact it is SW and Vader obviously plays a large role but I would rather play an amazingly graphical immersive game that is less than an hour than a low repetitive polygon with cartoon graphics.

I think this is a win and excited as to where VR games go in general if this quality is the benchmark. If they decided to make 10 of the next episodes I would buy all at once if necessary and delete all other games as the thrill and return on this type of experience is awesome. It will be the first game I show someone new to VR.

Quality over quantity and having both Rift and Quest, I never had expectations the Quest could have such a great quality game on it.

The reality is you are likely never going to find a 20 hour game with such great immersion, gameplay, and graphics these days given the specs which is why we see so many polygon repetitive games. Basically, longer arcade-style vs. shorter gaming experiences is where we are at. Spec limiting as the driver for the length I have to assume. If you can come to grips with that and know what your preference is in your pack of games to have- you will love this game for what it is! A new dawn of VR gaming.

It's short for the price but I cannot take away the 5 for that in this case given the joy it gave me.
